briefing.opening: Good morning, everyone. We will now begin the climate briefing for February 27, 2026.

sections.title: ğŸ”´ International Community's Climate Crisis Warnings and Policy Challenges
sections.content: Today, the international community has reported warnings about the accelerating severity of climate change, alongside moves by some nations towards policy reversals. Scientists have warned that the current rate of warming is the fastest in at least three million years, potentially locking the Earth into a 'hothouse future' [57]. Concrete changes are also being observed, such as shorter winters in 80% of major U.S. cities [59]. Of particular concern are reports that the U.S. Trump administration deleted climate change-related data [37], withdrew findings on greenhouse gas risks, and moved to abolish vehicle greenhouse gas standards and chemical disaster prevention systems, raising international alarm [47, 60]. It is noted that such policy reversals could pose a serious obstacle to global climate response efforts, for instance, by leaving Mozambique vulnerable to the climate crisis [43]. Climate change is amplifying destructive storms on the Iberian Peninsula [49], slowing the birth rate of Southern Right Whales [44], and severely impacting the Arctic regions of Greenland [41, 45], indicating widespread threats to global ecosystems.

sections.title: ğŸ‡°ğŸ‡· Domestic Climate Change Response and Carbon Neutrality Efforts
sections.content: Domestically, diverse efforts are actively underway to address climate change and achieve carbon neutrality. The pre-reopening inspection of the Cheongju Land Climate Change Experience Center [1] and Gimhae City's plan to host the '2026 Carbon Neutrality Lifestyle Practice Competition' [17] are expected to contribute to fostering public climate awareness and encouraging practical action. Korea Water Resources Corporation (K-water) has demonstrated a leading role among public institutions by hosting a new green algae technology forum and expanding international cooperation with the UN to strengthen water and climate change resilience in the Asia-Pacific region [3, 4, 5]. Furthermore, various local governments and organizations, including Incheon City, Pyeongtaek City, and Guri City Volunteer Center, are actively accelerating carbon neutrality practices in the public sector [6, 9], seeking carbon neutrality and river management solutions with citizens [13], and promoting carbon neutrality projects [16]. Meanwhile, a system that awards carbon neutrality points for purchasing products made with recycled materials [10, 18] is encouraging citizen participation. However, the delay in legislation despite the impending deadline for amending the 'Framework Act on Carbon Neutrality' [14] remains a challenge to be resolved in the advancement of domestic climate policy.

sections.title: ğŸŒ± Accelerating Renewable Energy Transition and Technological Innovation
sections.content: Globally, the transition to renewable energy is accelerating, with ongoing efforts to enhance efficiency through the adoption of innovative technologies. Domestically, policy support is strengthening, with the Ministry of Climate launching a public-private committee to boost offshore wind competitiveness [7], and the Korea New and Renewable Energy Association and the Federation of Organizations welcoming the expansion of tax credits for solar power investment [22, 23]. Particularly encouraging examples include Daegu Metropolitan City achieving the top rank nationwide in renewable energy deployment through its 'Solar Power Great Transformation' [24], and Jeonbuk region's plan to be developed into a future industry hub for AI, robotics, and renewable energy [21, 31]. Korea Southern Power (KOSPO) is increasing operational efficiency by showcasing renewable energy facility inspection and safety management technologies utilizing drones and AI [26, 29, 30, 33], and LS ELECTRIC is also leading technological innovation by predicting renewable energy generation with AI [25]. Internationally, the expansion of renewable energy is spreading, with India accelerating its carbon neutrality goals by commencing construction of eco-friendly data centers [15], and Uzbekistan shifting its energy strategy from natural gas to solar power [36].

sections.title: ğŸŒ Global Climate Action and Voices for Sustainability
sections.content: The international community's awareness of climate change is progressively deepening, with various stakeholders urging action for a sustainable future. In Washington State, arguments have been made for maintaining a continuous flow of carbon funds to combat climate change [38], and legal and institutional approaches are becoming more active, with climate change-related issues being addressed in court [42]. Scientists believe the world remains unprepared for climate change and are calling for a global assessment [54], while countries like Malaysia are facing tangible threats, including an increase in deaths due to climate change-related issues [56]. However, there is also hopeful news. In the Brazilian Amazon, indigenous activists achieved a significant environmental protection victory by preventing the privatization of waterways [61], and a Taiwanese minister praised the EU for 'leading' the response to climate change [58], indicating ongoing international cooperation and community action. These movements serve as crucial drivers for transformative change towards global sustainability [52].

briefing.closing: In today's briefing, we examined the international community's warnings regarding the climate crisis and the policy challenges, while also reporting on active climate change response efforts both domestically and internationally, and the acceleration of renewable energy transition. Climate change is the most urgent challenge facing humanity, and through continuous attention and cooperation, we will build a sustainable Earth for future generations. This concludes today's climate briefing.
